text: If your Mac won't connect to Wi-Fi,
or if your connection drops out
for seemingly mysterious reasons,
there's several solutions you can try.
We will be going over seven ways

to troubleshoot your
Mac's Wi-Fi connection
and get your computer back up and running.
First, let's verify that we are connected
to the correct Wi-Fi network.

Click the Wi-Fi symbol to
open the Wi-Fi drop-down menu.

Verify that the preferred
network is the correct network.
If it is not, then open "Other Networks"
and select the correct Wi-Fi connection.

Now it's a good time to
switch between your 2.5-

and 5-gigahertz networks
if you have both set up.

Sometimes a simple switch
from one to the other
will restore your Wi-Fi connection.

Next, let's try checking
the wireless diagnostics.

Open "Spotlight Search" and
look up "Wireless Diagnostics."
Then, open it.

Now click "Continue," and
this will run the diagnostics.
If no problems are found,

you can click "Monitor
my Wi-Fi Connection,"
which will create a log of information

for a technician to look at
and help diagnose your problem.

Now let's check to see if
there are any system updates
that will help correct your issue.

Click the Apple icon and
open "About This Mac,"
then click "Software Update."
Your Mac will then search for updates
and let you know if any are available.

If there are available
updates, click "Update Now."
Next, let's check to see if your router
and/or modem is at fault.

Turning these off and then back
on again can fix your issue.

Unplug your cable modem
and wireless router
if they're not an all-in-one unit.

Wait 30 seconds, then plug
your cable modem back in first,
and then your wireless router.
Now we're getting a little more technical.

It's possible that your
Wi-Fi is working fine,

but you aren't getting
your internet access

because your internet service
provider's Domain Name System,
or DNS, isn't working properly.

In cases like this, try using
a free public DNS instead.
Google has a good one.
To try this, click your Wi-Fi icon,
and then open "Network Preferences."

Click "Advanced." Then select
"DNS" from the menu options,

hit the plus icon, and add
Google's DNS addresses:

Click "OK," and try
browsing the internet again.

NVRAM, or non-volatile
random access memory,
and PRAM, parameter random access memory,

are two internal Mac components
that store the memory
even when the device is turned off.

This is used in places like
your computer's internal clock.

And resetting the PRAM and
NVRAM can be an effective way
to clear out your virtual cobwebs
and get your Wi-Fi up and running again.

You can also reset the SMC, or
system management controller,
while you're there for the same reason.

Apple has articles published
with more information
on what the NVRAM, PRAM, and SMC do,
which we will link in the description.
For PRAM and NVRAM, start the computer,
and after you hear the startup chime,
hold "Shift," "Control" and "Option" keys

while you press the power
button for at least 10 seconds.
To reset the PRAM individually,
after you hear the startup chime,

press and hold "Command,"
"Option," "P," and "R" keys.

To reset the SMC, it depends
on whether you have a Mac model
with a removable battery or not.
If you happen to have a removable battery,
all you have to do is remove it

and hold down the power
button for five seconds.
On all other Macs,

press "Shift," "Control," "Option,"
and hold the power button.

Hold these keys for 10
seconds, and release.

When all else fails,
restart your computer.

It may be the oldest trick
in the book, but it can work.
And if it doesn't,

and you've exhausted
all your other options,
this may be a clue

that your connection problems
are hardware-related,
either on your computer or at the router.
